newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal's BPI 1996 profit rises 56 pct.
newsitem.headline: Portugal's BPI 1996 profit rises 56 pct.

text.p: Banco Portugues de Investimento, Portugal's fourth biggest private bank, reported a 56 percent increase in 1996 profits to 15.1 billion escudos ($90 million) on Wednesday, in line with analysts' expectations.
The board decided to propose a gross dividend of 85 escudos per share, which represents a five percent increase over the 100 escudos paid in 1995, adjusted for a capital increase at the end of 1995.
BPI said its 1996 results were not directly comparable with those of 1995 because of the acquisition of state controlled bank Banco de Fomento e Exterior (BFE) in August 1996.
"The consolidation of BFE took place from October 1, 1996, and so the results include BFE's accounts for the last quarter of 1996," a statement said.
BPI said goodwill of 47 billion escudos from the acquisition of BFE was amortised in its 1996 accounts by a transfer from reserves and that it would have no impact on future results.
BPI raised its provisions sharply, well above the requirements of the Bank of Portugal, to 17.5 billion escudos, including a seven billion escudo adjustment due to the purchase of BFE.
The bank gave no figures for provisions for 1995.
BPI's assets rose 108 percent year-on-year to 2.89 trillion escudos ($17.2 billion) in 1996. Loans increased by 178 percent year-on-year to 1.16 trillion escudos ($6.9 billion).
BPI shares eased in early trade on Lisbon bourse to 2,555 escudos, down 24, in volume of 25,209 shares. $1=168.2 escudos
